docs.lead_paragraph: SKOLNICK--Allen, died on Wednesday, April 24th, after a brief illness. He was 84 years old. Allen Skolnick was a successful business executive, a devoted family man, a major philanthropist and a lover of horses and horseracing. He was born in New York City and received his bachelor's degree in chemistry and biology from New York University. In 1970 he first became associated with the Solgar Company, a pioneering developer and marketer of dietary supplements which was originally established in 1947. He maintained a lifelong interest in the science of nutrition and wellness. Allen was the President of Solgar in 1998 when it was sold to American Home Products Corp. In 1995, Allen and his wife Connie established the CAMBR Foundation which has supported numerous national not-for-profit organizations for nearly fifteen years, including the American Jewish Committee, Hillel Foundation, Birthright Israel, the Weizmann Institute of Science and American Friends of Hebrew University. He and Connie were the principals of Southwind Farms, headquartered in Pennington, New Jersey which remains a premiere breeding farm for standard bred horses. The Skolnick family was involved in the ownership, training and racing of several championship standard bred race horses. Allen was predeceased by his wife Connie and by one of their sons, Rand Skolnick. Survivors include his brother, Edward, of Atlanta; his sons, Mitchel and Barry Skolnick; grandsons Ryan, Matthew and Jacob Skolnick, as well as many dear friends of long good standing who knew Allen and Connie in their varied interests and activities. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the CAMBR Foundation, 410 Ocean Avenue, Lynbrook, New York 11563. Services to be private.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new column from Mark Bittman explores moderate, conscious eating: a diet higher in plants and lower in animal products and hyperprocessed foods.
docs.abstract: Mark Bittman introduces The Flexitarian column, through which he will explore conscious eating with a diet higher in plants and lower in animal products and processed foods.
docs.snippet: A new column from Mark Bittman explores moderate, conscious eating: a diet higher in plants and lower in animal products and hyperprocessed foods.

docs.lead_paragraph: Children who do not show physical symptoms of konzo, a crippling disease caused by the cyanide in improperly prepared cassava, may still have mental impairments.

headline.seo: In Central Africa, Bitter Cassava Is Linked to Mental Deficits

docs.abstract: Dr Michael J Boivin study in journal Pediatrics shows that children in Central African villages who do not show signs of crippling disease konzo may still have significant mental impairment; konzo is caused by eating bitter cassava, common root vegetable in region, that has not been prepared properly in order to break down its natural high levels of cyanide.
docs.snippet: Children who do not show physical symptoms of konzo, a crippling disease caused by the cyanide in improperly prepared cassava, may still have mental impairments.
